A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a ring includes the requirement that the set R, with respect to multiplication, forms a monoid. A monoid is defined as a set that is closed under an associative binary operation and has an identity element. Therefore, the associative law is explicitly required for the operation of multiplication in the definition of a ring. This means that the concept of the Associative Law must be defined and understood for the definition of a ring to be complete and make sense. Without the associative property of multiplication, the structure would not meet the criteria of a monoid, and hence would not satisfy the definition of a ring.
